Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero's '70s trilogy broke down barriers, proving that mainstream audiences wouldn't cheat on their genre duties for big budget movies from Ridley Scott or Stanley Kubrick. Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit in judgement on murders - "crossing red light? eh, that guy got what he deserved. I'm fining him 75 USD and demanding he pay for his own funeral!".
